items.title: Tasmanians to feel the burn as severe heatwave conditions arrive
items.description: As Tasmanians make the most of the first heatwave of 2026, authorities are keeping a keen eye on reported high rates of dry grass and other bushfire risks.

items.title: Firefighters face challenging conditions in Vic and SA as heatwave begins
items.description: Firefighters in Victoria and South Australia are bracing for challenging conditions as a heatwave threatens to bring temperatures of above 45C to some parts of the country.

items.title: US pledges to back European force in Ukraine if Russia attacks

featured_image.name: Zelensky Turns to Europe After Talks With U.S. Officials

items.description:
The United States has pledged to support a European-led multinational force in Ukraine and lead ceasefire monitoring efforts under binding security commitments finalized at a Paris summit Tuesday, marking a significant shift in Western policy toward preventing future Russian aggression.

Draft statements from the gathering of the "Coalition of the Willing" indicate Washington will head a "continuous, reliable ceasefire monitoring system" with international participation following any peace agreement[1][2][3][4]. The US will also provide intelligence and logistics support to European forces deployed in Ukraine and commit to backing them "in case of attack" by Russia[1][2][3].

French President Emmanuel Macron is hosting representatives from 35 countries, including 27 heads of state, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, and US envoys Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner, at the Élysée Palace[5][6][7]. The meeting aims to finalize contributions to security guarantees that Ukraine requires to deter further Russian aggression after nearly four years of war.

items.title: Trump's intervention in Venezuela is beyond comparison
items.description: The global shock caused by the Trump administration's interventions Venezuela sent analysts scurrying for historic comparisons but nothing really compares to what happened this week.

items.title: White House refuses to rule out force in Greenland push

featured_image.name: Stephen Miller Asserts U.S. Has Right to Take Greenland

items.description:
White House Deputy Chief of Staff Stephen Miller asserted Monday that Greenland should become part of the United States, questioning Denmark's sovereignty over the Arctic territory and refusing to rule out the use of military force to acquire it[1][2]. The statements, made during a CNN interview, triggered sharp rebukes from European leaders who warned that such action would threaten the NATO alliance and upside decades of post-World War II security cooperation[3][4].

"Nobody is going to fight the United States militarily over the future of Greenland," Miller said when pressed repeatedly about whether Washington would rule out military intervention[5][6]. He challenged Denmark's territorial claims, asking "by what right does Denmark assert control over Greenland?"[7][2]

The comments came days after a provocative social media post by Miller's wife, Katie Miller, who shared an image Saturday of Greenland covered in the American flag with the caption "SOON"[8][9]. The post followed closely on the heels of a U.S. military operation in Venezuela that captured President Nicolás Maduro, raising international concerns about the Trump administration's willingness to use force against sovereign nations.

items.title: China bans dual-use exports to Japanese military

featured_image.name: China Bans Exports of Dual-Use Items to Japan Military Users ...

items.description:
China announced on Tuesday an immediate ban on all exports of dual-use items to Japanese military end-users, marking the latest escalation in a diplomatic crisis between Asia's two largest economies that has deepened since November[1][2][3].

The ban, issued by China's Ministry of Commerce, prohibits the export of goods with both civilian and military applications to any Japanese military users or for purposes that could enhance Japan's defense capabilities[1][2][3]. The ministry warned that organizations or individuals from any country that violate the restrictions will face legal consequences[4][5][3].

Dual-use items encompass a wide range of technologies and materials including semiconductors, drones, chemicals, laser systems, satellite communication equipment, and advanced computing devices—products that serve commercial purposes but can also be adapted for military applications[6][7][8].

items.title: European leaders rally behind Greenland amid threats of a Trump take-over
items.description: The US president and his officials are continuing to push for an American take over of the Danish territory, saying the island is needed for national security.

items.title: Japanese teams advance quantum computing with error correction breakthrough

featured_image.name: IBM and RIKEN Unveil First IBM Quantum System Two Outside of ...

items.description:
Japanese research teams are making parallel strides in quantum computing, with scientists at Institute of Science Tokyo achieving near-theoretical performance in error correction while RIKEN develops software to merge quantum computers with supercomputers.

A team led by Associate Professor Kenta Kasai at Institute of Science Tokyo has developed quantum error-correction codes that approach the theoretical limit known as the hashing bound, according to research published in npj Quantum Information[1][2][3][4]. The codes achieved a frame error rate as low as 10⁻⁴ for systems with hundreds of thousands of qubits, with decoding complexity that scales proportionally to the number of physical qubits—addressing a major barrier to practical quantum computing[1][2].

Traditional quantum error-correction methods hit an accuracy ceiling far below theoretical limits, requiring heavy computation that made large-scale systems impractical[1][2]. Kasai and Master's student Daiki Komoto constructed low-density parity-check codes defined over non-binary finite fields that handle both bit-flip and phase-flip errors simultaneously[3][5]. "Our quantum error-correcting code has a greater than 1/2 code rate, targeting hundreds of thousands of logical qubits," Kasai said[3][4]. The breakthrough could enable quantum computers to scale to millions of logical qubits, potentially advancing drug discovery, cryptography and climate prediction[1][6].

items.title: One in five solar panels degrades twice as fast as expected, UNSW study finds

featured_image.name: Shedding Light on Solar Panel Degradation - Exponent

items.description:
Researchers at the University of New South Wales have uncovered a troubling pattern in solar panel performance, finding that approximately 20% of panels examined degrade much more rapidly than industry expectations, potentially lasting only half their anticipated 25-year lifespan.

The study, published in IEEE and released January 5, analyzed data from nearly 11,000 photovoltaic systems worldwide to investigate what scientists call the "long tail" problem—where a subset of panels fails far more quickly than the average degradation rate[1][2][3].

"Most solar systems are designed to last around 25 years, based on their warranty period," said Yang Tang, a PhD student at UNSW's School of Photovoltaic and Renewable Energy Engineering and co-author of the paper[1][3][4]. "For the entire dataset, we observed that system performance typically declines by around 0.9% per year. However, at least one in five systems degrade at least 1.5 times faster than this typical rate, and roughly one in 12 degrade twice as fast."

For operators of solar farms where hundreds of thousands of panels are installed, the findings represent a hidden financial risk that challenges the economic models underpinning the industry's growth[1][2][3].

items.title: Nvidia AI boom drives laptop prices up 15-20%

featured_image.name: Nvidia CEO: This AI 'breakthrough' is 'completely genius'

items.description:
Nvidia unveiled its most powerful AI computing platform yet at CES 2026 on Monday, even as the chip giant's insatiable demand for memory components drives laptop prices to unprecedented heights, leaving consumers caught in the crossfire of the artificial intelligence boom.

The company's Rubin platform, announced by CEO Jensen Huang in Las Vegas, promises five times the AI performance of its predecessor while slashing computing costs[1][2][3][4]. But the same AI revolution powering Nvidia's dominance is creating a global memory shortage that has forced major PC makers to implement steep price increases starting this week[5][6][7].

items.title: US set to back Ukrainian defence coalition if peace deal made with Russia
items.description: A draft statement outlines what Ukraine's allies could commit to if Russia attacks its neighbour again in the future.

items.title: Boston Dynamics unveils Atlas robot, partners with Google DeepMind

featured_image.name: Hyundai Motor Group To Accelerate Human–Robot Collaboration in ...

items.description:
Boston Dynamics publicly demonstrated its Atlas humanoid robot for the first time on Monday at CES 2026 in Las Vegas, marking a milestone in the company's decades-long effort to bring industrial robots from laboratory prototypes to factory floors[1][2][3][4].

"For the first time ever in public, please welcome Atlas to the stage," said Zachary Jackowski, Boston Dynamics' vice president and general manager for humanoid robots, as the 5-foot-9, 200-pound machine rose from the floor of a Las Vegas hotel ballroom[1][3][4]. The robot walked fluidly across the stage for several minutes, waving to the crowd and swiveling its head in owl-like motions[1][3][4].

items.title: UN condemns US military operation in Venezuela

featured_image.name: At the U.N., Even Allies Condemn U.S. Action in Venezuela

items.description:
The United Nations Human Rights Office issued a sharp rebuke Tuesday of the US military operation in Venezuela, warning that the intervention undermines international law and makes "all states less safe around the world."[1][2][3][4]

Speaking at a media briefing in Geneva, Ravina Shamdasani, spokesperson for UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Volker Turk, said the operation "violated a fundamental principle of international law" that prohibits states from using force against the territorial integrity or political independence of another state.[1][5][2] "It sends a signal that the powerful can do whatever they like," Shamdasani told reporters.[2][4][6]

The criticism follows the January 3 US military strike on Venezuela that resulted in the capture of President Nicolas Maduro and his wife, Cilia Flores. More than 150 US aircraft bombed military installations across Caracas in the predawn operation, codenamed "Absolute Resolve," before special forces extracted Maduro from the Venezuelan capital.[7][8] Venezuelan officials reported at least 80 people were killed, including civilians.[8]

items.title: Nvidia, AMD, Intel unveil AI chips at CES 2026

featured_image.name: Watch the NVIDIA CES 2026 keynote with CEO Jensen Huang live here: AI, robotics updates and more

items.description:
The opening day of CES 2026 delivered a cascade of artificial intelligence and semiconductor announcements as industry giants Nvidia, AMD, and Intel unveiled new chips and AI platforms targeting everything from data centers to laptops.

In keynote presentations on Monday, January 5—a day before CES officially opened its doors—the three chipmakers outlined their visions for what Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang called "physical AI," signaling a shift from cloud-based systems to AI that powers robots, autonomous vehicles, and everyday devices.

items.title: Nikkei 225 closes at record high in historic Asian rally

featured_image.name: AI Bubble Fears and Policy Splits Loom Over Asia Stocks in 2026

items.description:
Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 closed at a record high on Tuesday, capping a historic opening to 2026 for Asian equities as investors pivoted away from U.S. markets toward regional tech stocks and AI-related investments[1][2].

The Nikkei 225 gained 1.3% to close at 52,518.08, surpassing its previous record set on October 31[1][3]. The rally was led by technology-related shares, including precision tools maker Disco Corp., which surged 6.1%[1]. The broader TOPIX index also reached an all-time high[4][5].
